input:
1. A 15-year-old female presents with gradually worsening balance difficulties and frequent falls over the past two years. Her parents report slow speech development and increasing clumsiness since early childhood. On examination, she has dysarthria, limb ataxia, and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Muscle tone is decreased, and deep tendon reflexes are diminished. There is no family history of similar neurological symptoms. MRI reveals cerebellar atrophy without significant spinal cord involvement. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia, Autosomal Recessive 25 due to biallelic mutations in the gene associated with this condition. Supportive therapy with physical rehabilitation is initiated to improve coordination and prevent falls.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The doctor is asking why I'm here today, so I should explain what’s been bothering me, but I might not be very clear or specific about it. I need to mention my symptoms and how they've been making me feel, maybe sounding a bit worried or uncertain since I don’t fully understand everything myself. I should keep it simple and honest, just sharing what I notice day to day.

ANSWER: Um, I’m here because I’ve been falling a lot and I feel sort of unsteady, like I can’t keep my balance. It’s been getting worse over the last couple of years, and I don’t really understand what’s wrong or why it’s happening. It’s kind of scary sometimes, and I just want to see if there’s anything that can help.

input: 1. A 15-year-old female presents with gradually worsening balance difficulties and frequent falls over the past two years. Her parents report slow speech development and increasing clumsiness since early childhood. On examination, she has dysarthria, limb ataxia, and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Muscle tone is decreased, and deep tendon reflexes are diminished. There is no family history of similar neurological symptoms. MRI reveals cerebellar atrophy without significant spinal cord involvement. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia, Autosomal Recessive 25 due to biallelic mutations in the gene associated with this condition. Supportive therapy with physical rehabilitation is initiated to improve coordination and prevent falls.Can you tell me more about how your unsteadiness and falls have changed over time, and if there are any specific situations or activities that make them worse or better?
output: Um, I guess I’ve been worse over time...like, I fall more often now, even just walking around the house. Sometimes I feel kind of wobbly, like I can’t really balance, especially if I’m trying to do more than one thing at once. It’s better when I sit still, but even then, I feel like I might tip over sometimes.

input: 1. A 15-year-old female presents with gradually worsening balance difficulties and frequent falls over the past two years. Her parents report slow speech development and increasing clumsiness since early childhood. On examination, she has dysarthria, limb ataxia, and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Muscle tone is decreased, and deep tendon reflexes are diminished. There is no family history of similar neurological symptoms. MRI reveals cerebellar atrophy without significant spinal cord involvement. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia, Autosomal Recessive 25 due to biallelic mutations in the gene associated with this condition. Supportive therapy with physical rehabilitation is initiated to improve coordination and prevent falls.Can you tell me how your symptoms affect your daily activities and whether there are particular times or situations when your unsteadiness feels worse or better?
output: Um, I guess I just feel kind of wobbly most of the time, and sometimes I fall more than I used to. Like, if I’m trying to focus on something or if I’m tired, it gets worse, I think. It’s really confusing because I don’t always know when I’ll be okay or when I’ll stumble.

input: 1. A 15-year-old female presents with gradually worsening balance difficulties and frequent falls over the past two years. Her parents report slow speech development and increasing clumsiness since early childhood. On examination, she has dysarthria, limb ataxia, and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Muscle tone is decreased, and deep tendon reflexes are diminished. There is no family history of similar neurological symptoms. MRI reveals cerebellar atrophy without significant spinal cord involvement. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia, Autosomal Recessive 25 due to biallelic mutations in the gene associated with this condition. Supportive therapy with physical rehabilitation is initiated to improve coordination and prevent falls.Can you describe a typical episode or situation when your unsteadiness or falls happen, and whether you notice any patterns or other symptoms that occur along with these episodes?
output: Umm, I think it just kind of happens when I’m walking or sometimes even when I’m standing still. It’s like I suddenly lose my balance, and I fall or almost fall. I don’t really notice anything special happening before it, and it’s not always the same, really. Sometimes I feel a bit dizzy or like my eyes go funny, but I’m not sure if that’s always there.

input: 1. A 15-year-old female presents with gradually worsening balance difficulties and frequent falls over the past two years. Her parents report slow speech development and increasing clumsiness since early childhood. On examination, she has dysarthria, limb ataxia, and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Muscle tone is decreased, and deep tendon reflexes are diminished. There is no family history of similar neurological symptoms. MRI reveals cerebellar atrophy without significant spinal cord involvement. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia, Autosomal Recessive 25 due to biallelic mutations in the gene associated with this condition. Supportive therapy with physical rehabilitation is initiated to improve coordination and prevent falls.Are you experiencing any other neurological symptoms such as tremors, muscle stiffness, abnormal eye movements, difficulty swallowing or speaking, or changes in blood pressure or heart rate?
output: Um, I guess I sometimes notice my eyes kind of move weird when I look to the side, and I feel like my speech sometimes sounds strange or hard to control. I haven’t really thought about blood pressure or heart rate, honestly.

input: 1. A 15-year-old female presents with gradually worsening balance difficulties and frequent falls over the past two years. Her parents report slow speech development and increasing clumsiness since early childhood. On examination, she has dysarthria, limb ataxia, and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Muscle tone is decreased, and deep tendon reflexes are diminished. There is no family history of similar neurological symptoms. MRI reveals cerebellar atrophy without significant spinal cord involvement. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia, Autosomal Recessive 25 due to biallelic mutations in the gene associated with this condition. Supportive therapy with physical rehabilitation is initiated to improve coordination and prevent falls.Have you noticed any difficulty or slowness in moving your eyes vertically, such as trouble looking down or up? Also, do you experience any other symptoms like rigidity, limb stiffness, sensory changes, or autonomic issues like blood pressure fluctuations?
output: Um, I think my eyes move okay, I guess? I haven’t really paid attention to looking up or down, but I don’t feel like my eyes are acting weird or anything. And I don’t really notice my limbs feeling stiff or strange or anything like that. I don’t think I’ve felt any changes like blood pressure or anything.

input: 1. A 15-year-old female presents with gradually worsening balance difficulties and frequent falls over the past two years. Her parents report slow speech development and increasing clumsiness since early childhood. On examination, she has dysarthria, limb ataxia, and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Muscle tone is decreased, and deep tendon reflexes are diminished. There is no family history of similar neurological symptoms. MRI reveals cerebellar atrophy without significant spinal cord involvement. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia, Autosomal Recessive 25 due to biallelic mutations in the gene associated with this condition. Supportive therapy with physical rehabilitation is initiated to improve coordination and prevent falls.Do you notice any particular difficulty moving your eyes vertically, such as looking down or up? Are there any other neurological symptoms like muscle stiffness, tremors, or changes in blood pressure or heart rate that you've experienced?
output: Um, I don’t really notice much with my eyes, like I don’t think I can look up or down differently. Sometimes I feel a bit dizzy or off, but I’m not really sure if it’s connected. I haven’t noticed anything about my muscles being stiff or tremors, no. Sometimes my heartbeat feels weird or fast, but I don’t know if that’s normal or not.

input: 1. A 15-year-old female presents with gradually worsening balance difficulties and frequent falls over the past two years. Her parents report slow speech development and increasing clumsiness since early childhood. On examination, she has dysarthria, limb ataxia, and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Muscle tone is decreased, and deep tendon reflexes are diminished. There is no family history of similar neurological symptoms. MRI reveals cerebellar atrophy without significant spinal cord involvement. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia, Autosomal Recessive 25 due to biallelic mutations in the gene associated with this condition. Supportive therapy with physical rehabilitation is initiated to improve coordination and prevent falls.Have you noticed any difficulty moving your eyes vertically, such as trouble looking down or up, or any persistent problems with eye movements when looking to the sides? Would you be comfortable discussing how these symptoms affect your daily activities, and exploring possible management strategies together?
output: Um, sometimes... my eyes feel weird, like when I try to look down or up, it kinda jerks or doesn’t move right? It makes things look odd, and I guess it bugs me when I’m trying to read or look at stuff. I don’t really know how to talk about it, but it makes me feel kind of tired.

input: 1. A 15-year-old female presents with gradually worsening balance difficulties and frequent falls over the past two years. Her parents report slow speech development and increasing clumsiness since early childhood. On examination, she has dysarthria, limb ataxia, and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Muscle tone is decreased, and deep tendon reflexes are diminished. There is no family history of similar neurological symptoms. MRI reveals cerebellar atrophy without significant spinal cord involvement. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia, Autosomal Recessive 25 due to biallelic mutations in the gene associated with this condition. Supportive therapy with physical rehabilitation is initiated to improve coordination and prevent falls.Have you noticed any persistent difficulty or trouble when trying to look up or down with your eyes? If so, could you tell me how this affects your daily activities and whether these eye movement issues seem to improve or worsen over time?
output: Yeah, sometimes it's hard for me to look up or down, like my eyes just don't want to move the way I want them to. It makes it hard to read stuff or look at things above me, and it feels worse sometimes if I try to look up quickly. It's kind of annoying, and I think it gets worse when I’m tired or anxious.
